content:
Diagnosis:	Metastatic neuroendocrine prostate carcinoma with rhabdoid features
	Initial diagnosis March 2023
	Molecular profile: TP53/RB1/PTEN/CYLD loss
	PSA consistently <0.1
?
[redacted name] has unfortunately experienced significant clinical deterioration over the past three weeks. Following his initial diagnosis of this rare and aggressive variant of prostate cancer in March 2023, he initially responded well to first-line carboplatin/etoposide chemotherapy, achieving partial response after 4 cycles. However, following completion of 6 cycles in August 2023, surveillance imaging showed early disease progression with new liver lesions.?
?
Second-line treatment with pembrolizumab was commenced in September 2023 but discontinued after 2 cycles due to immune-related hepatitis requiring high-dose steroids. Following recovery, he commenced docetaxel in November 2023, completing 4 cycles with stable disease as best response before developing progressive symptoms in January 2024.?
?
He presented to the Emergency Department last week with severe headaches and ataxia. MRI brain demonstrated multiple dural-based metastases with the largest measuring 3.2cm in the right posterior fossa causing early cerebellar compression. He received urgent dexamethasone and whole brain radiotherapy (20Gy in 5 fractions, completed yesterday).?
?
On review today, his performance status has declined to ECOG 3. He requires wheelchair assistance and reports ongoing headaches (though improved from presentation), severe fatigue, poor appetite with 6kg weight loss over 1 month, and new right-sided chest pain. His wife reports he is sleeping most of the day.?
?
On examination, he is cushingoid from steroids but alert and oriented. There is mild right-sided cerebellar signs with past-pointing and dysdiadochokinesia. Chest examination reveals reduced air entry at the right base with dullness to percussion, suggesting possible pleural effusion.?
?
Given his poor performance status and aggressive disease trajectory despite multiple lines of therapy, I have had a detailed discussion with [redacted name] and his wife about focusing on quality of life and symptom control. They understand and agree with transition to best supportive care. I have made an urgent referral to the palliative care team and arranged community support. He will be reviewed by them tomorrow, and I will maintain oversight of his care with weekly telephone reviews. I have provided emergency contact numbers and educated about red flag symptoms.?
?
Please do not hesitate to contact us if you require any additional information regarding his care.
